standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve real world problems involving multiplication of fractions and mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.

question.content: $\dfrac13$ of the students in Mrs. Holl’s class have dogs.  Of those students, $\dfrac25$ have beagles.    **What fraction of the students in Mrs. Holl’s class have beagles?**   of the students

hints.content: $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac13}$  of the students in Mrs. Holl's class have beagles.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three bars. The bars are left-aligned but different lengths. The top bar is the longest. It is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the bar is labeled All students. The middle bar is shorter than the top bar. It is labeled one-third. A curved bracket below the bar is labeled Students with dogs. The bottom bar is the shortest bar. It is labeled two-fifths of one-third, A bracket below the bar is labeled Students with beagles.

hints.content: $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac13}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac25} \times \purpleE{\dfrac13}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{\dfrac25}\text{ of }\purpleE{\dfrac13} &= \blueE{\dfrac25} \times \purpleE{\dfrac13}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueE2 \times \purpleE1}{\blueE5 \times \purpleE3}\\\\ &= \dfrac2{15} \end{align}$
$\dfrac2{15}$ of the students in Mrs. Holl's class have beagles.

question.content: $\dfrac15$ of the animals at a zoo are monkeys.  $\dfrac57$ of the monkeys are male.    **What fraction of the animals at the zoo are male monkeys?**   of the animals

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac57}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac15}$ of the animals at the zoo are male monkeys.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three bars. The bars are left-aligned but different lengths. The top bar is the longest. It is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the bar is labeled Animals at the zoo. The middle bar is shorter than the top bar. It is labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below the bar is labeled Monkeys. The bottom bar is the shortest bar. It is labeled five-sevenths of one-fifth, A bracket below the bar is labeled Male monkeys.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac57}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac15}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac57} \times \purpleD{\dfrac15}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac57}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac15} &= \blueD{\dfrac57} \times \purpleD{\dfrac15}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5 \times \purpleD1}{\blueD7 \times \purpleD5}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\stackrel{\blueD1}{\cancel{\blueD5}} {}\times \purpleD1 }{  \blueD7 \times \underset{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD5}} } \\\\ &= \dfrac1{7} \end{align}$
$\dfrac17$ of the animals at the zoo are male monkeys.

question.content: Talia spent $\dfrac34$ of this week's allowance on candy. Of the money she spent on candy, $\dfrac56$ was spent on gummy bears.  **What fraction of this week's allowance did Talia spend on gummy bears?**   of this week's allowance

hints.content: Talia spent $\blueD{\dfrac56}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac34}$ of this week's allowance on gummy bears.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three bars. The bars are left-aligned but different lengths. The top bar is the longest. It is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the bar is labeled Allowance. The middle bar is shorter than the top bar. It is labeled three-fourths. A curved bracket below the bar is labeled Spent on candy. The bottom bar is the shortest bar. It is labeled five-sixths of three-fourths, A bracket below the bar is labeled Spent on gummy bears.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac56}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac34}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac56} \times \purpleD{\dfrac34}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac56}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac34} &= \blueD{\dfrac56} \times \purpleD{\dfrac34}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5 \times \purpleD3}{\blueD6 \times \purpleD4}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5\times{}\stackrel{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD3}}  }{ \underset{\blueD2}{\cancel{\blueD6}}\times\purpleD4 } \\\\ &= \dfrac5{8} \end{align}$
Talia spent $\dfrac5{8}$ of this week's allowance on gummy bears.

question.content: Rapunzel cut off $\dfrac23$ of her hair. She donated $\dfrac78$ of what she cut off to a wig shop.  **What fraction of her hair did Rapunzel donate?**   of her hair

hints.content: Rapunzel donated $\blueD{\dfrac78}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac23}$of her hair.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three bars. The bars are left-aligned but different lengths. The top bar is the longest. It is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the bar is labeled Rapunzel's hair length. The middle bar is shorter than the top bar. It is labeled two-thirds. A curved bracket below the bar is labeled Cut hair. The bottom bar is the shortest bar. It is labeled seven-eighths of two-thirds. A bracket below the bar is labeled Donated hair.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac78}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac23}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac78} \times \purpleD{\dfrac23}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac78}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac23} &= \blueD{\dfrac78} \times \purpleD{\dfrac23}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD7 \times \purpleD2}{\blueD8 \times \purpleD3}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD7\times{}\stackrel{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD2}}  }{ \underset{\blueD4}{\cancel{\blueD8}}\times\purpleD3 } \\\\ &= \dfrac7{12} \end{align}$
Rapunzel donated $\dfrac7{12}$ of her hair.

question.content: $\dfrac23$ of the doughnuts in a box have frosting. $\dfrac12$ of the doughnuts with frosting have sprinkles.   **What fraction of the doughnuts in the box have frosting and sprinkles?**   of the doughnuts

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac12}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac23}$ of the doughnuts in the box have frosting and sprinkles.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three bars. The bars are left-aligned but different lengths. The top bar is the longest. It is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the bar is labeled Whole box. The middle bar is shorter than the top bar. It is labeled 2/3. A curved bracket below the bar is labeled Frosting. The bottom bar is the shortest bar. It is labeled one-half of two-thirds. A bracket below the bar is labeled Frosting and sprinkles.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac12}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac23}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac12} \times \purpleD{\dfrac23}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac12}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac23} &= \blueD{\dfrac12} \times \purpleD{\dfrac23}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD1 \times \purpleD2}{\blueD2 \times \purpleD3}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD1\times{}\stackrel{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD2}}  }{ \underset{\blueD1}{\cancel{\blueD2}}\times\purpleD3 } \\\\ &= \dfrac1{3} \end{align}$
$\dfrac13$ of the doughnuts in the box have frosting and sprinkles.

question.content: Priya spent $1\dfrac12$ days hiking. She was lost $\dfrac56$ of the time that she was hiking.   **What fraction of a day was Priya lost?**   days

hints.content: Priya was lost $\blueD{\dfrac56}$ of $\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$ days.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled one and one-half days. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Time spent hiking. The bottom bar is  labeled five-sixths of one and one-half days. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Time lost.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac56}$ of $\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac56} \times \purpleD{1\dfrac12}$.

Let's change $\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{1\dfrac12} &= \purpleD{1} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac22} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD2+\purpleD1}\purpleD2\\\\ &=\purpleD{\dfrac32} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac56}\text{ of }\purpleD{1\dfrac12} &= \blueD{\dfrac56} \times \purpleD{\dfrac32}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5 \times \purpleD3}{\blueD6 \times \purpleD2}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5\times{}\stackrel{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD3}}  }{ \underset{\blueD2}{\cancel{\blueD6}}\times\purpleD2 } \\\\ &= \dfrac5{4}\\\\ &= 1\dfrac1{4} \end{align}$
Priya was lost $1\dfrac1{4}$ days.

question.content: Natasha spent $1\dfrac12$ hours on the beach. She fell asleep for $\dfrac34$ of the time she was on the beach and then woke up with a terrible sunburn.  **How many hours was Natasha asleep on the beach?**   hours

hints.content: Natasha was asleep $\dfrac34$ of $1\dfrac12$ hours.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled one and one-half hours. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Time at beach. The bottom bar is  labeled three-fourths of one and one-half hours. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Time spent sleeping on the beach.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac34}$ of $\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac34}\times\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$.

Let's change $\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{1\dfrac12} &= \purpleD{1} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac22} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD2+\purpleD1}\purpleD2\\\\ &=\purpleD{\dfrac32} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac34}\text{ of }\purpleD{1\dfrac12} &= \blueD{\dfrac34} \times \purpleD{\dfrac32}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD3 \times \purpleD3}{\blueD4 \times \purpleD2}\\\\ &= \dfrac9{8}\\\\ &= 1\dfrac1{8} \end{align}$
Natasha was asleep on the beach $\dfrac98$ hours.  We can also write this as $1\dfrac18$ hours.

question.content: A punch bowl had $2\dfrac12$ liters of juice in it.  Liam drank $\dfrac13$ of the juice in the bowl.    **How many liters of juice did Liam drink?**   of a liter

hints.content: Liam drank $\blueD{\dfrac13}$ of $\purpleD{2\dfrac12}$ liters of juice.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled two and one-half liters. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Juice in the bowl. The bottom bar is  labeled one-third of two and one-half liters. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Amount Liam drank.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac13}$ of $\purpleD{2\dfrac12}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac13} \times \purpleD{2\dfrac12}$.

Let's change $\purpleD{2\dfrac12}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{2\dfrac12} &= \purpleD{1} +\purpleD{1} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac22} +\purpleD{\dfrac22} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD2+\purpleD2+\purpleD1}\purpleD2\\\\ &=\purpleD{\dfrac52} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac13}\text{ of }\purpleD{2\dfrac12} &= \blueD{\dfrac13} \times \purpleD{\dfrac52}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD1 \times \purpleD5}{\blueD3 \times \purpleD2}\\\\ &= \dfrac5{6} \end{align}$
Liam drank $\dfrac56$ of a liter of juice.

question.content: At the candy store, Sophie filled a bag with $2\dfrac23$ kilograms of candy. $\dfrac14$ of the weight of the candy was from chocolate covered pretzels.    **How much did the chocolate covered pretzels in Sophie's bag weigh?**   of a kilogram

hints.content: The chocolate covered pretzels weighed $\blueD{\dfrac14}$ of $\purpleD{2\dfrac23}$ kilograms.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled two and two-thirds kilograms. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Weight of candy bag. The bottom bar is labeled one-fourth of two and two-thirds kilograms. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Weight of pretzels.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac14}$ of $\purpleD{2\dfrac23}$ is another way of saying $\blueD{\dfrac14} \times \purpleD{2\dfrac23}$.

Let's change $\purpleD{2\dfrac23}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{2\dfrac23} &= \purpleD{1} +\purpleD{1} +\purpleD{\dfrac23}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac33} +\purpleD{\dfrac33} +\purpleD{\dfrac23}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD3+\purpleD3+\purpleD2}\purpleD3\\\\ &=\purpleD{\dfrac83} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac14}\text{ of }\purpleD{2\dfrac23}&= \blueD{\dfrac14} \times \purpleD{\dfrac83}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD1 \times \purpleD8}{\blueD4 \times \purpleD3}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD1\times{}\stackrel{\purpleD2}{\cancel{\purpleD8}}  }{ \underset{\blueD1}{\cancel{\blueD4}}\times\purpleD3 } \\\\ &= \dfrac23 \end{align}$
The chocolate covered pretzels in Sophie's bag of candy weighed $\dfrac23$ of a kilogram.

question.content: Jackie loves to cook fried foods. She recorded the total amount of oil that she used each month in the table below.   In January, she used $\dfrac35$ of the amount of oil that she used in February.  **Fill in the amount of oil that Jackie used in January in the table below.**  Month | Liters of oil used :-: | :-:  January  |  February | $\dfrac23$ March | $1\dfrac12$

hints.content: Jackie used $\purpleD{\dfrac35}$ of $\blueD{\text{February's amount}}$ in January.   She used $\blueD{\dfrac23 \text{ of a liter}}$ in February.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled two-thirds liters. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Amount of oil in February. The bottom bar is  labeled three-fifths of two-thirds liters. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Amount of oil in January.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\dfrac35}$ of $\blueD{\dfrac23}$ is another way of saying $\purpleD{\dfrac35}\times\blueD{\dfrac23}$.

$\begin{align} \purpleD{\dfrac35}\text{ of }\blueD{\dfrac23} &= \purpleD{\dfrac35} \times \blueD{\dfrac23}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD3\times\blueD2}{\purpleD5 \times \blueD3}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\stackrel{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD3}} \times ~\blueD2}{~\purpleD5 \times \underset{\blueD1}{\cancel{\blueD3}}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD1\times\blueD2}{\purpleD5 \times \blueD1}\\\\ &= \dfrac{2}{5} \end{align}$
Jackie used $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of a liter of oil in January.

question.content: Bill paints murals. He recorded the total amount of white paint that he used for his murals each month in the table below.   In April, Bill used $\dfrac23$ of the amount that he used in March.  **Fill in the amount of white paint Bill used in April in the table below.**  Month | Liters of white paint used :-: | :-:  March | $\dfrac45$ April |  May | $1\dfrac14$

hints.content: Bill used $\blueD{\dfrac23}$ of $\purpleD{\text{March's amount}}$ in April.   He used $\purpleD{\dfrac45 \text{ of a liter}}$ in March.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled four-fifths liters. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Paint used in March. The bottom bar is  labeled two-thirds of four-fifths liters. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Paint used in April.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\dfrac23}$ of $\blueD{\dfrac45}$ is another way of saying $\purpleD{\dfrac23}\times\blueD{\dfrac45}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac23}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac45} &= \blueD{\dfrac23} \times \purpleD{\dfrac45}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD2 \times \purpleD4}{\blueD3 \times \purpleD5}\\\\ &= \dfrac8{15} \end{align}$
Bill used $\dfrac8{15}$ of a liter of white paint in April.

question.content: Eric has started running for exercise. He recorded the number of kilometers he ran each day this week in the table below.   On Monday, Eric ran $\dfrac57$ of the distance that he ran on Friday.  **Fill in the number of kilometers that Eric ran on Monday in the table below.**  Day | Number of kilometers run :-: | :-:  Monday |   Wednesday | $1\dfrac12$ Friday | $\dfrac9{10}$

hints.content: Eric ran $\blueD{\dfrac57}$ of $\purpleD{\text{Friday's distance}}$ on Monday.   He ran $\purpleD{\dfrac9{10} \text{ of a kilometer}}$ on Friday.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled nine-tenths kilometers. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Friday's distance. The bottom bar is  labeled five-sevenths of nine-tenths kilometers. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Monday's distance.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\dfrac57}$ of $\blueD{\dfrac9{10}}$ is another way of saying $\purpleD{\dfrac57}\times\blueD{\dfrac9{10}}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac57}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac9{10}} &= \blueD{\dfrac57} \times \purpleD{\dfrac9{10}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5 \times \purpleD9}{\blueD7 \times \purpleD{10}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\stackrel{\blueD1}{\cancel{\blueD5}} {}\times \purpleD9 }{  \blueD7 \times \underset{\purpleD2}{\cancel{\purpleD{10}}} } \\\\ &= \dfrac9{14} \end{align}$
Eric ran $\dfrac9{14}$ of a kilometer on Monday.

question.content: Julia has a role in the school play. She recorded the amount of time she practiced her lines each day this week in the table below.   On Tuesday, she practiced $\dfrac23$ of the time that she practiced on Wednesday.  **Fill in the number of hours that Julia practiced her lines on Tuesday in the table below.**  Day | Hours practiced :-: | :-:  Monday |  $\dfrac34$ Tuesday |  Wednesday | $\dfrac56$

hints.content: Julia practiced $\blueD{\dfrac23}$ of $\purpleD{\text{Wednesday's hours}}$ on Tuesday.   She practiced $\purpleD{\dfrac5{6} \text{ of an hour}}$ on Wednesday.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the top bar is longer than the bottom bar. The top bar is labeled five-sixths hours. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Wednesday's time. The bottom bar is  labeled two-thirds of five-sixths hours. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Tuesday's time.

hints.content: $\purpleD{\dfrac23}$ of $\blueD{\dfrac56}$ is another way of saying $\purpleD{\dfrac23}\times\blueD{\dfrac56}$.

$\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac23}\text{ of }\purpleD{\dfrac56} &= \blueD{\dfrac23} \times \purpleD{\dfrac56}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD2 \times \purpleD5}{\blueD3 \times \purpleD{6}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\stackrel{\blueD1}{\cancel{\blueD2}} {}\times \purpleD5 }{  \blueD3 \times \underset{\purpleD3}{\cancel{\purpleD{6}}} } \\\\ &= \dfrac5{9} \end{align}$
Julia practiced her lines $\dfrac5{9}$ of an hour on Tuesday.

question.content: The dolphins at the San Diego zoo eat $3\dfrac18$ buckets of fish each day. The killer whales eat $2\dfrac35$ times as much fish as the dolphins.  **How many buckets of fish do the killer whales eat each day?**    buckets

hints.content: The killer whales eat $2\dfrac35$ times the amount of the dolphins' $3\dfrac18$ buckets.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the bottom bar is longer than the top bar. The top bar is labeled three and one-eighth buckets. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Amount dolphins eat. The bottom bar is  labeled two and three-fifths times three and one-eighth buckets. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Amount whales eat.

hints.content: To find the amount of buckets the killer whales eat, we multiply:   $\purpleD{2\dfrac35}\times\blueD{3\dfrac18}$

Let's change $\purpleD{2\dfrac35}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{2\dfrac35} &= \purpleD{2} +\purpleD{\dfrac35}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac55} + \purpleD{\dfrac55} +\purpleD{\dfrac35}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD5 +\purpleD5 +\purpleD3}\purpleD5\\\\ &=\purpleD{\dfrac{13}{5}} \end{align}$

Now, let's change $\blueD{3\dfrac18}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \blueD{3\dfrac18} &= \blueD{3} +\blueD{\dfrac18}\\\\ &= \blueD{\dfrac88} + \blueD{\dfrac88} + \blueD{\dfrac88} +\blueD{\dfrac18}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD8+\blueD8+\blueD8+\blueD1}\blueD8\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{25}8} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \purpleD{2\dfrac{3}5} \times \blueD{3\dfrac{1}8} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{13}5} \times \blueD{\dfrac{25}8} \\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{13}\times\blueD{25}}{\purpleD5 \times \blueD8}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{13}\times{}\stackrel{\blueD5}{\cancel{\blueD{25}}}  }{ \underset{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD5}}\times\blueD8 } \\\\ &= \dfrac{65}{8}\\\\ &=8\dfrac{1}{8} \end{align}$
The killer whales eat $8\dfrac{1}{8}$ buckets of fish each day.

question.content: Carlos spent $1\dfrac14$ hours doing his math homework. He spent $1\dfrac14$ as much time practicing piano.  **How many hours did Carlos spend practicing piano?**   hours

hints.content: Carlos spent $1\dfrac14$ times $1\dfrac14$ hours practicing piano.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the bottom bar is longer than the top bar. The top bar is labeled one and one-fourth hours. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Time on math. The bottom bar is  labeled one and one-fourth times one and one-fourth hours. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Time on piano.

hints.content: Let's change ${1\dfrac14}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} {1\dfrac14} &= {1} +{\dfrac14}\\\\ &= {\dfrac44} +{\dfrac14}\\\\ &= \dfrac{4+1}4\\\\ &={\dfrac{5}{4}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \purpleD{1\dfrac{1}4} \times \blueD{1\dfrac{1}4} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{5}4} \times \blueD{\dfrac{5}4} \\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{5}\times\blueD{5}}{\purpleD4 \times \blueD4}\\\\ &= \dfrac{25}{16}\\\\ &=1\dfrac{9}{16} \end{align}$
Carlos spent $1\dfrac9{16}$ hours practicing piano.

question.content: Junior's brother is $1\dfrac12$ meters tall.  Junior is $1\dfrac15$ of his brother's height.    **How tall is Junior?**    meters

hints.content: Junior is $1\dfrac15$ times $1\dfrac12$ meters tall.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two bars. The bars are left-aligned, but the bottom bar is longer than the top bar. The top bar is labeled one and one-half meters. A curved bracket above the top bar is labeled Junior’s brother’s height. The bottom bar is  labeled one and one-fifth times one and one-half meters. A curved bracket below the bottom bar is labeled Junior’s height.

hints.content: Let's change $\purpleD{1\dfrac12}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{1\dfrac12} &= \purpleD{1} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac22} +\purpleD{\dfrac12}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD2+\purpleD1}\purpleD2\\\\ &=\purpleD{\dfrac32} \end{align}$

Now, let's change $\blueD{1\dfrac15}$ into a fraction.  $\begin{align} \blueD{1\dfrac15} &= \blueD{1} +\blueD{\dfrac15}\\\\ &= \blueD{\dfrac55}  +\blueD{\dfrac15}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD5+\blueD1}\blueD5\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{6}5} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \purpleD{1\dfrac12} \times \blueD{1\dfrac{1}5} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}2} \times \blueD{\dfrac{6}5} \\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{3}\times\blueD{6}}{\purpleD2 \times \blueD5}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{3}\times{}\stackrel{\blueD3}{\cancel{\blueD{6}}}  }{ \underset{\purpleD1}{\cancel{\purpleD2}}\times\blueD5 } \\\\ &= \dfrac{9}{5}\\\\ &=1\dfrac{4}{5} \end{align}$
Junior is $1\dfrac{4}{5}$ meters tall.
